review_title: Good Resources & Great Student Body, Questionable Management & Lack of Accountability
pros: It's easy to work and fundraise for a place when you believe in the missions and values. The student body is driven, smart, opinionated, hard-working, and kind-hearted. There are adequate financial resources to run and grow programs incrementally. Supervisors are generally open to flexing time as long as the work gets done. Directors are open to discussion and hearing new ideas. Resources are available for professional development (attending conference, webinars, etc.).
cons: It feels like there is a general lack of motivation among staff to take initiative and to accomplish tasks and complete projects effectively and efficiently. Also, many staff members are not held accountable to performing their job duties.. As a result, things a slow-moving, there is often push-back when hard work is required, and a select few folks end up doing significantly more work to compensate for other members of the team. Depending on team leadership, new ideas and projects are difficult to implement because they get stuck in the project proposal stage. Also, as with many work places, microaggressions are an issue. There is a general lack of initiative at the team leadership level to address issues around diversity and inclusion in the workplace. It takes a lot of prompting and follow up from administrative staff to see any action/engagement, which is disheartening and leads to low morale.

job_title: Assistant Dean of Students in Claremont, CA
pros: Good student services and for staff.
cons: Overworked and the pay isn't fair.

pros: Working under a faculty member has allowed me to develop a good relationship with one of the professors in my field of study. It's a good learning opportunity, offers flexible hours, and decent enough pay.

job_title: Assistant Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Benefits are nice: staff fitness program, health insurance, dental, vision. Pet insurance a plus. Tuition benefit is ok. 

Nice facilities, offices. Good food in dining halls. Beautiful grounds. Close commute (for some, not all). Not sure how anyone affords to live in the area. Near a big transit hub.

Good people - committed to success of their departments/students. Helpful to know where to look & who to go to if you want to get things done.
cons: Relatively new to campus so I don’t have a sense of “how things used to be.” Joined during a leadership transition year. Subsequently, there have been challenges. Messaging, consistency, transparency - typical issues during periods of change. Hard to stay motivated when hearing about all the turnover. Hard to take on more work and responsibilities for the low pay. Hard to be at a place that sounds & seems great on the outside and face the reality that it’s as dysfunctional as anywhere else.

pros: It's almost impossible to be fired if you put in a good effort and do as you're asked. The work study atmosphere is very supportive and nurturing; employers genuinely want to see you get something beyond money out of the experience. I feel like a valuable team member at my work-study despite not being a full time worker. The job pays well and has hours that fit my schedule.
cons: The work can be a little redundant at times. Not much opportunity for upward growth, but it is a work study position after all.

pros: Pomona College is a great college with many amenities of its employees. Benefits are great, full gym access, discounted movie tickets, and even employee events.
cons: Management is self indulgent, and is heavily concerned with looking out for its own best interest. Contrary to what the college states, salaries are not up to industry standard. This is not a personal opinion, it is a fact.

pros: Great people, great community, claremont is a beautiful place to work.  The brightest team of admissions officers you could possibly work for.
cons: Environment is a bit high-strung, but it's kind of understandable considering Pomona is ranked very highly across the country.  A lot of power given to senior positions at Admissions Office

review_title: Good for those who love the college
pros: Meet new and interesting students; talking about yourself for an hour; exercise (one tour guide counted their steps on an hour long tour--10,000 in total); opportunity to practice public speaking and interpersonal skills; free t-shirt/in n out
cons: Tours are occasionally inconvenient timed (ie could have midterm right after); tours can be awkward

review_title: Not as Good as it Looks
pros:
Great benefits (Retirement contribution, wellness program, carpool reimbursement, tuition remission)
Commitment to diversity of student body, staff & faculty
Beautiful campus
Smart people
cons:
Leadership has changed and the climate has changed too. Last year, I would have given culture and values 5 stars.
Low pay
Very little opportunity for advancement
Condescending, egocentric, arrogant  attitudes of some people in leadership positions

review_title: It was a great experience, but there were no options for career improvement
pros: Full board and accommodation are included. It is an amazing opportunity to study and live in California. There are many opportunities for traveling and the director of Oldenborg Center is a great human being who will always be there to help you.
cons: There are no chances for career improvement or to develop transferable skills. It would be great to help workers start a career in education or international education.

review_title: A positive place to work with great benefits but few advancement opportunities
pros: Positive work environment (people tend to be happy); great benefits; good work-life balance; supportive colleagues; with lectures, concerts and performances, a lot of cultural and intellectual opportunities. A lot of free food at talks and after meetings that other employees can scavenge! Claremont is a quaint, beautiful town to work in.
cons: Very little to no opportunity for advancement or skills-building; lack of salary growth. Stress has increased.

pros: The best part about Pomona is the incredibly talented student body and faculty. In addition, the facilities and endowment make working at Pomona an excellent experience.
cons: The relative isolation from Los Angeles was less than perfect. I couldn't help but find myself wishing that it were closer to a major city.

review_title: For a small college, they have a surprising number of resources and all faculty and staff are fairly attentive.
pros: The community is close and the weather is great! I like the way they approach academics here - they want the students to understand the process of the scientific method.
cons: It can be small, so if you don't like your department, there's not much you can do but most departments are well-oiled and convenient.

review_title: I always felt welcome and the co workers were very professional
pros: Amazing campus where I got to meet a lot of intelligent people. Very flexible schedule working as a student at Star 47: The annual fund.
cons: may be stressful but easy to move up in ranks when you try to give it all you can and work at improving your calls.

* super flexible hours
* very colloquial environment
* get to help other students

* great team
cons:
* see the same types of problems over and over
* some other students don't take the job as seriously as one might hope
